pages.text: $(thing)Linear Accelerators$() are used to either create particle beams and increase their energy and focus or to increase the energy and focus of an existing particle beam.

pages.title: Construction
pages.text: Linear Accelerators are a rectangular prism of $(item)Accelerator Casings$() and or $(item)Accelerator Glass$() that must be five blocks wide and tall. $(l:accelerators/general)Like all accelerators$(/l), they require $(item)Accelerator Coolant Vents$() in both input and output mode, an $(item)Accelerator Energy Port$(), and a $(item)Linear Accelerator Controller$().

pages.title: Construction Cont.
pages.text: There must be a continuous line of $(item)Accelerator Beam Blocks$() down the center of the accelerator. Where the beam blocks meet the casing on either side, there must be an $(item)Accelerator Ion Source$() (or an Accelerator Beam Port in input mode for using an existing beam) on one side, and an $(item)Accelerator Beam Port$() in output mode at the other.

pages.title: Energy
pages.text: The energy of the particles created by the accelerator can be calculated using the equation $(thing)E=S+|q|V$(), where $(thing)S$() is the particle's starting energy, $(thing)q$() is the particle's charge, and $(thing)V$() is the accelerator voltage, which is the sum of the voltages of all of the RF cavities within the accelerator.

pages.title: Ion source
pages.text: The $(item)Ion Source$() is the beginning of any $(thing)Particle Beam$(). The $(item)Accelerator Ion Source$() must be supplied with a source item to create the particle beam. The source will be depleted up after a certain amount of active use, so it must be continually replaced for the accelerator to continue functioning.
